name: Vector
definition: A quantity with both magnitude and direction, essential in physics for representing displacement, velocity, and force; for example, adding vectors using head-to-tail method or components in Cartesian coordinates.

name: Scalar
definition: A quantity with only magnitude, no direction, such as mass, time, or speed; contrasted with vectors, scalars add algebraically without considering direction.

name: Position
definition: The location of an object relative to a reference point, often denoted as a vector r; in one dimension, it's a signed scalar indicating distance from origin.

name: Displacement
definition: The vector change in position, Delta r = r_f - r_i, measuring straight-line distance and direction from start to end, independent of path taken.

name: Velocity
definition: The rate of change of position, v = dr/dt, with average velocity as v_avg = Delta r / Delta t; instantaneous velocity is the limit as Delta t -> 0.

name: Acceleration
definition: The rate of change of velocity, a = dv/dt, causing changes in speed or direction; average acceleration is a_avg = Delta v / Delta t.

name: Kinematic Equations
definition: Set of equations for constant acceleration motion: v = v_0 + a t, x = x_0 + v_0 t + (1/2) a t^2, v^2 = v_0^2 + 2 a (x - x_0), x = x_0 + (1/2) (v_0 + v) t; used to solve for unknowns in linear motion.

name: Projectile Motion
definition: Two-dimensional motion under constant gravity, with horizontal velocity constant (v_x = v_0x) and vertical acceleration a_y = -g; trajectory is parabolic, range formula R = (v_0^2 sin 2 theta)/g.

name: Relative Motion
definition: Motion observed from different frames; velocity of A relative to B is v_{A/B} = v_A - v_B, crucial for problems like river crossing or airplane in wind.

name: Free Fall
definition: Motion under gravity alone, with acceleration g ≈ 9.8 m/s^2 downward; all objects fall at same rate in vacuum, independent of mass.

name: Newton's First Law
definition: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force; also known as the law of inertia.

name: Newton's Second Law
definition: The net force on an object equals mass times acceleration, F_net = m a; force is a vector, and this law defines inertial mass.

name: Newton's Third Law
definition: For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force; forces come in pairs acting on different objects, like rocket propulsion.

name: Inertia
definition: The resistance of an object to changes in its motion, proportional to mass; explains why heavier objects require more force to accelerate.

name: Free Body Diagram
definition: A diagram showing all forces acting on an object, used to find net force; includes weight, normal force, friction, tension, etc., with vectors from the object's center.

name: Weight
definition: The gravitational force on an object, W = m g, directed downward; not the same as mass, varies with location.

name: Normal Force
definition: The perpendicular force exerted by a surface on an object, equal to the component of weight perpendicular to the surface on a horizontal plane; adjusts on inclines.

name: Friction
definition: Force opposing relative motion; kinetic friction f_k = mu_k N, static friction f_s <= mu_s N, where mu is the coefficient, direction opposite to tendency of motion.

name: Tension
definition: The pulling force in a rope or string, uniform in ideal massless ropes; used in Atwood machines or pulley systems.

name: Apparent Weight
definition: The perceived weight in accelerating frames, like in elevators; equals normal force, increases when accelerating upward.

name: Inclined Plane
definition: A sloped surface where components of gravity are parallel (m g sin theta) and perpendicular (m g cos theta) to the plane; used to analyze sliding with friction.

name: Centripetal Force
definition: The net force toward the center in circular motion, F_c = (m v^2)/r; provided by tension, friction, or gravity, not a new force type.

name: Work
definition: The transfer of energy by force along displacement, W = integral F dot dr; for constant force, W = F d cos theta, scalar quantity in joules.

name: Kinetic Energy
definition: Energy of motion, K = (1/2) m v^2; work-kinetic energy theorem states W_net = Delta K.

name: Potential Energy
definition: Stored energy due to position; gravitational U_g = m g h, spring U_s = (1/2) k x^2, conservative forces have path-independent work.

name: Conservation of Mechanical Energy
definition: In isolated systems with only conservative forces, K_i + U_i = K_f + U_f; non-conservative forces like friction dissipate energy as heat.

name: Power
definition: Rate of work done, P = dW/dt = F dot v; average power P_avg = W / Delta t, in watts.

name: Conservative Force
definition: A force where work is independent of path, like gravity or electrostatic; associated with potential energy function, curl is zero in vector calculus.

name: Momentum
definition: The product of mass and velocity, p = m v; conserved in isolated systems, vector quantity.

name: Impulse
definition: Change in momentum, J = integral F dt = Delta p; for constant force, J = F Delta t.

name: Conservation of Linear Momentum
definition: In isolated systems with no external forces, total momentum is constant; applies to collisions and explosions.

name: Elastic Collision
definition: Collision where both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved; for equal masses in 1D, velocities exchange.

name: Inelastic Collision
definition: Collision where momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not; perfectly inelastic when objects stick together.

name: Center of Mass
definition: The average position of mass in a system, r_cm = (sum m_i r_i)/M; motion follows Newton's laws as if all mass there.

name: Rocket Propulsion
definition: Application of momentum conservation where expelled gas provides thrust, F = -v_e dm/dt, variable mass systems.

name: Torque
definition: The rotational analog of force, tau = r x F, magnitude tau = r F sin theta; causes angular acceleration.

name: Angular Velocity
definition: Rate of change of angular position, omega = d theta / dt; related to linear velocity by v = r omega.

name: Angular Acceleration
definition: Rate of change of angular velocity, alpha = d omega / dt; Newton's second for rotation: tau_net = I alpha.

name: Moment of Inertia
definition: Rotational inertia, I = integral r^2 dm; for point mass I = m r^2, depends on axis and mass distribution.

name: Parallel Axis Theorem
definition: I = I_cm + M d^2, where d is distance from center of mass to new axis; used to find I for offset axes.

name: Rotational Kinetic Energy
definition: K_rot = (1/2) I omega^2; added to translational for total energy in rolling without slipping.

name: Angular Momentum
definition: L = r x p, or for rotation L = I omega; conserved when no external torque.

name: Conservation of Angular Momentum
definition: In isolated systems with no external torque, total L constant; explains figure skater spinning faster when arms pulled in.

name: Rolling Without Slipping
definition: Condition where v = r omega, a = r alpha; friction provides torque but does no work if static.

name: Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM)
definition: Oscillatory motion where restoring force proportional to displacement, F = -k x; position x = A cos (omega t + phi), omega = 2 pi f = 2 pi / T.

name: Period
definition: Time for one complete cycle, T; for mass-spring T = 2 pi sqrt(m/k), independent of amplitude in SHM.

name: Frequency
definition: Cycles per second, f = 1/T; angular frequency omega = sqrt(k/m) for spring.

name: Pendulum
definition: SHM for small angles, T = 2 pi sqrt(L/g); physical pendulum T = 2 pi sqrt(I / (m g d)).

name: Energy in SHM
definition: Total E = (1/2) k A^2 = constant, oscillating between kinetic and potential.

name: Damped Oscillation
definition: SHM with energy loss due to friction, amplitude decreases exponentially; under, critical, over-damped cases.

name: Driven Oscillation
definition: Oscillator with external periodic force; resonance when driving frequency matches natural, maximizing amplitude.

name: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
definition: F = G (m_1 m_2)/r^2, attractive force between masses; G = 6.67 × 10^{-11} Nm²/kg².

name: Gravitational Field
definition: g = -G M / r^2 (direction toward mass), acceleration due to gravity; inside uniform sphere, linear with r.

name: Gravitational Potential Energy
definition: U = -G (m_1 m_2)/r, zero at infinity; escape velocity v_esc = sqrt(2 G M / r).

name: Orbital Motion
definition: Circular orbits: v = sqrt(G M / r), period T^2 = (4 pi^2 / G M) r^3 from Kepler's third law.

name: Kepler's Laws
definition: 1. Elliptical orbits with sun at focus; 2. Equal areas in equal times; 3. T² ∝ a³ for semi-major axis a.

name: Black Hole
definition: Region where escape velocity exceeds light speed, Schwarzschild radius r_s = 2 G M / c^2; event horizon.

name: Charge
definition: Fundamental property causing electromagnetic force; conserved, quantized in e = 1.6 × 10^{-19} C, positive/negative.

name: Coulomb's Law
definition: F = k (q_1 q_2)/r^2, k = 9 × 10^9 Nm²/C²; similar to gravity but repulsive/attractive.

name: Electric Field
definition: E = F / q_0, force per unit charge; for point charge E = k q / r^2, vector field.

name: Gauss's Law
definition: Closed integral E dot dA = Q_encl / epsilon_0, relates flux to enclosed charge; useful for symmetric charge distributions.

name: Electric Potential
definition: Potential energy per charge, V = U / q; for point charge V = k q / r, scalar, work by field negative of Delta U = q Delta V.

name: Equipotential Surface
definition: Surface where V is constant; E perpendicular to it, no work moving charges along it.

name: Electric Dipole
definition: Two equal opposite charges separated by d; moment p = q d, torque tau = p x E, potential energy - p dot E.

name: Conductor
definition: Material with free charges; in electrostatics, E=0 inside, excess charge on surface, V constant throughout.

name: Capacitor
definition: Device storing charge, C = Q/V; parallel plate C = epsilon_0 A / d, energy U = (1/2) C V^2.

name: Dielectric
definition: Insulator in capacitor reducing E by kappa, increasing C by kappa; polarization creates bound charges.

name: Capacitors in Series/Parallel
definition: Series: 1/C_eq = sum 1/C_i; parallel: C_eq = sum C_i.

name: Electric Current
definition: I = dQ/dt, flow of charge; drift velocity in conductors.

name: Ohm's Law
definition: V = I R, resistance R = rho L / A; for ohmic materials, linear V-I.

name: Kirchhoff's Loop Rule
definition: Sum of voltage changes around loop zero, conservation of energy.

name: Kirchhoff's Junction Rule
definition: Sum of currents into junction equals out, conservation of charge.

name: Resistors in Series/Parallel
definition: Series: R_eq = sum R_i; parallel: 1/R_eq = sum 1/R_i.

name: RC Circuit
definition: Charging: q = Q (1 - e^{-t/tau}), tau = R C; discharging: q = Q e^{-t/tau}.

name: Power in Circuits
definition: P = I V = I^2 R = V^2 / R, energy dissipation as heat.

name: Magnetic Field
definition: Field causing force on moving charges; created by currents, magnets.

name: Magnetic Force on Charge
definition: F = q v x B, right-hand rule; circular motion in uniform B.

name: Magnetic Force on Wire
definition: F = I L x B, for straight wire.

name: Biot-Savart Law
definition: dB = (mu_0 / 4 pi) (I dl x r-hat)/r^2, for current elements.

name: Ampere's Law
definition: Closed integral B dot dl = mu_0 I_encl, for symmetric currents like solenoids.

name: Solenoid
definition: Coil with uniform B inside B = mu_0 n I, n turns per length.

name: Lorentz Force
definition: F = q (E + v x B), combined electric and magnetic.

name: Faraday's Law
definition: Emf = - d Phi_B / dt, induced emf from changing magnetic flux Phi_B = integral B dot dA.

name: Lenz's Law
definition: Induced current opposes change in flux, conservation of energy.

name: Motional Emf
definition: Emf = B L v, for rod moving in B field.

name: Inductance
definition: L = Phi_B / I, self-inductance; energy U = (1/2) L I^2.

name: RL Circuit
definition: Growth: I = (Emf / R) (1 - e^{-t/tau}), tau = L/R; decay similar.

name: LC Circuit
definition: Oscillations at omega = 1/sqrt(L C), energy alternating between L and C.

name: Maxwell's Equations
definition: Set of four equations unifying E&M: Gauss's for E and B, Faraday's, Ampere's with displacement current; predict electromagnetic waves.

name: Hooke's Law
definition: The restoring force exerted by an ideal spring is directly proportional to the displacement from its equilibrium position and directed opposite to it, expressed as F = -k x, where k is the spring constant; forms the basis for simple harmonic motion in springs.

name: Rotational Equilibrium
definition: The state in which the net torque acting on a system is zero, resulting in no angular acceleration; combined with translational equilibrium (net force zero) for complete static equilibrium of rigid bodies.

name: Banked Curve
definition: A curved roadway inclined at an angle to the horizontal to provide the necessary centripetal force through the component of the normal force, with ideal banking angle satisfying tan θ = v² / (r g), assuming no friction.

name: Electric Flux
definition: A measure of the electric field passing through a given surface, calculated as Φ_E = ∫ E ⋅ dA, where the integral is over the surface; central to Gauss's Law, which states Φ_E = Q_enclosed / ε₀ for a closed surface.

name: Electric Potential Energy
definition: The potential energy associated with the position of charges in an electric field, U = q V for a test charge q at potential V; for a system of point charges, U = Σ (k q_i q_j / r_ij) over all pairs, with work done by the field equal to -ΔU.

name: Electromotive Force
definition: The work done per unit charge by a non-electrostatic source to move charges through a circuit, denoted as ε (emf); in a battery, the terminal voltage is ε - I r, accounting for internal resistance r.

name: Right-Hand Rule
definition: A mnemonic for determining the direction of magnetic fields, forces, or induced currents; for example, for the magnetic field around a current-carrying wire, point the thumb in the direction of current, and curled fingers indicate the field direction.

name: Displacement Current
definition: A term introduced by Maxwell to modify Ampere's Law, I_d = ε₀ dΦ_E / dt, representing the effect of a changing electric flux as equivalent to a current for producing magnetic fields; essential for the propagation of electromagnetic waves.

name: Electromagnetic Wave
definition: A transverse wave consisting of oscillating electric and magnetic fields perpendicular to each other and to the direction of propagation, traveling at the speed of light c = 1 / √(μ₀ ε₀) in vacuum; predicted by Maxwell's equations.

name: Mutual Inductance
definition: The property of two coils where a changing current in one induces an emf in the other, M = Φ_{21} / I_1, where Φ_{21} is the flux through coil 2 due to current I_1 in coil 1; basis for transformers and inductive coupling.
